subNodes.conversationText: root

<FirstName> and the abbess sat together at a plain table in the center of the refectory. Pharaoh hopped onto the table expectantly, and to <FirstName>'s surprise the abbess produced a silver dish loaded with nuts and kernels and put it in front of the much gratified crow. Knott, who had no need to eat anything and no means to do so, stood nearby.
[Continue.]

Then the abbess pulled a piece of red silk off something on the table to  reveal a beehive swarming with bees. She rolled back a sleeve. Her arm looked delicate and soft and surprisingly youthful. Then she plunged her hand into the hive, withdrew a fistful of honeycomb, and devoured it without embarrassment. As she was chewing the wax and licking little golden morsels from between her fingers she gestured for the witch to do the same.
"Do you have any utensils?"
"My, you're dainty! Here'a a spoon." She handed <FirstName> a wooden spoon. "The bees will be suspicious, though."
[Continue.]
It was true. The spoon agitated the bees. The abbess laughed as the young witch threw it down and darted away from the table.
[Continue.]
"Come back, come back. The honey is good, and the bees will do you no harm. Try it without the spoon this time."
<FirstName> complied.
But <FirstName> refused.
<FirstName> complied.

The honey was fragrant as well as sweet. It smelled like a July meadow gone gold from rainless days. And yet there was a bitterness to it. The sensations of childhood hovered, bee-like, at the edge of it, irrecoverable intensities belonging to the young witch's still younger self. <His/Her> tongue helped <him/her> to the truth:  the bitterness was not in the honey, which was sweet as sweet can be, but in having known still sweeter things.
[Continue.]
The abbess took more of the honeycomb, then the young witch took more, then the abbess, and so on, until none was left.
[Continue.]
Afterwards, the abbess studied the young witch, saying nothing but looking into <his/her> face unreservedly, the way an infant studies a stranger -- affectionate, curious, motiveless.
But <FirstName> refused.
"No? Very well. Permit me to finish before we talk."
[Continue.]

The abbess withdrew another huge portion honeycomb and shoved it into her mouth. Then another fistful, then another. The bees did not seem to mind the trespasses and almost seemed to encourage them, flying out of her way whenever she took more.
[Continue.]
Afterwards, the abbess studied the young witch, saying nothing but looking into <his/her> face unreservedly, the way an infant studies a stranger -- affectionate, curious, motiveless.
[Continue.]

Then they began talking -- or rather, the abbess did, for she was loquacious and had many stories at her disposal, and the young witch hardly got a word in edgewise. If the abbess was to be believed, heroes and villains and scoundrels of all kinds had come through the abbey, and she knew their histories in detail. Her stories always involved the abbey in some way, the abbey and its many rooms -- many more than <FirstName> had seen.
<FirstName> wondered if <he/she> would ever be a character in one of the abbess's stories.

Strangely, it didn't occur to <him/her> to ask the questions that would have come to most people in these circumstances. Do other people live in the abbey? Where are they? Why is it so big? What do the people -- or you, if you're the only one here -- believe, exactly? Where do you get the honey? The young witch didn't lack curiosity, but the nature of the place simply made the questions unthinkable.
[Continue.]
"...There are, of course, rooms I've never been in, though I've lived in these halls longer than you've lived in this world."
"Other rooms? Why haven't you gone into them?"
"They are locked, and my vows forbid me from opening the doors."
"Where are the keys?"

"I have the key, of course! The locks simply remind me of my vows; the key is my will; as long as I restrain my will and do not put key to lock, I keep my vows. More practically, the locks prevent others from wandering in who have no right to what's inside."
"And what is inside these rooms?"

She laughed long and hard. "You don't understand. I don't know, and I'm not supposed to know. I have taken vows so that I will never know. But," she said, with a twinkle in her eye, "you have not taken any such vows. Are you curious?"
"I am."
"Then follow me," she said, leaping up from the table. The sudden motion disturbed the bees.
<FirstName> followed the abbess.
But <FirstName> had spent too much time here already. <He/She> excused <him/her>self.
"I see." She sat back down.
[Continue.]

"Yes, yes. You have your quest to complete. You have indulged me enough. I hope the honey was a pleasant indulgence for you. But I cannot see you off without a gift. Take these boots; they may not suit you, but they should fit your odd companion," she said, gesturing to Knott.
"No," said the young witch, lying a little.
"Are you quite sure about that? Don't lie to an old woman."
"Very well, let me see these doors."
"Then follow me," she said, leaping up from the table. The sudden motion disturbed the bees.
"I'm sure. I must be going."

"Yes, yes. You have your quest to complete. You have indulged me enough. I hope the honey was a pleasant indulgence for you. But I cannot see you off without a gift. Take these boots; they may not suit you, but they should fit your odd companion," she said, gesturing to Knott.
"No. I must be going."

"Yes, yes. You have your quest to complete. You have indulged me enough. I hope the honey was a pleasant indulgence for you. But I cannot see you off without a gift. Take these boots; they may not suit you, but they should fit your odd companion," she said, gesturing to Knott.
But <FirstName> was tired of the abbess's endless stories and excused <him/her>self.
"Your vows?"

"The Abbey of Mortal Pleasaunce is consecrated to sensation. What's inside the locked rooms may be linked to sensation in some way but is not sensation proper. What those rooms hold is, I suppose, outside my purview."
"And what is inside these rooms?"
But <FirstName> was tired of the abbess's endless stories and excused <him/her>self.
But <FirstName> was tired of the abbess's endless stories and excused <him/her>self.
But <FirstName> was tired of the abbess's endless stories and excused <him/her>self.

"Yes, yes. You have your quest to complete. You have indulged me enough. I hope the honey was a pleasant indulgence for you. But I cannot see you off without a gift. Take these boots; they may not suit you, but they should fit your odd companion," she said, gesturing to Knott.
[Continue.]
The attention made the gourd shuffle slightly.
[Continue.]
Continue
Continue
<FirstName> sat and listened, humoring the old woman.

Strangely, it didn't occur to <him/her> to ask the questions that would have come to most people in these circumstances. Do other people live in the abbey? Where are they? Why is it so big? What do the people -- or you, if you're the only one here -- believe, exactly? Where do you get the honey? The young witch didn't lack curiosity, but the nature of the place simply made the questions unthinkable.
The stories were not without charm, but the young witch was impatient.

Strangely, it didn't occur to <him/her> to ask the questions that would have come to most people in these circumstances. Do other people live in the abbey? Where are they? Why is it so big? What do the people -- or you, if you're the only one here -- believe, exactly? Where do you get the honey? The young witch didn't lack curiosity, but the nature of the place simply made the questions unthinkable.
